member.name: T:SystemWeaver.Common.ConnectionEvents
member.summary: Class which implements the SystemWeaver IswEvent listener interface to expose the events as C# events.

member.name: T:SystemWeaver.Common.IswEvent
member.summary: Interface to implement if you want to listen to all SystemWeaver events.
member.remarks: In general you should not implement this class yourself. The SystemWeaver API provides SystemWeaverAPI.SWConnection.EventManager for easy access to SystemWeaver events as C# events.

member.name: T:SystemWeaver.Common.IswEvents
member.summary: The SystemWeaver events as C# events.

member.name: E:SystemWeaver.Common.IswEvents.Obj_AddFile
member.summary: Is triggered when you add a file to an item or issue, for example through . You only get an event if the obj has been read in into the cache.

member.name: E:SystemWeaver.Common.IswEvents.Obj_RemoveFile
member.summary: Is triggered when you remove a file from an item or issue, for example through . You only get an event if the obj has been read in into the cache.

member.name: E:SystemWeaver.Common.IswEvents.ProjectDefinition_AddView
member.summary: Is triggered when you add a view to a project definition. You only get an event if the project has been read in into the cache.

member.name: E:SystemWeaver.Common.IswEvents.ProjectDefinition_AddReport
member.summary: Is triggered when you add a report to a project definition. You only get an event if the project has been read in into the cache.

member.name: E:SystemWeaver.Common.IswEvents.ProjectDefinition_AddIssueType
member.summary: Is triggered when you add an issue type to a project definition. You only get an event if the project has been read in into the cache.

member.name: E:SystemWeaver.Common.IswEvents.ProjectDefinition_AddWorkflow
member.summary: Is triggered when you add a workflow to a project definition. You only get an event if the project has been read in into the cache.

member.name: E:SystemWeaver.Common.IswEvents.Workflow_AddStatus
member.summary: Is triggered when you add a workflow status to a workflow. You only get an event if the workflow has been read in into the cache.

member.name: E:SystemWeaver.Common.IswEvents.Workflow_AddTransition
member.summary: Is triggered when you add a transition to a workflow. You only get an event if the workflow has been read in into the cache.

member.name: T:SystemWeaver.Common.Internal.SWBranchInfo
member.summary: Contains utility functions for dealing with version numbers.

member.name: M:SystemWeaver.Common.Internal.SWBranchInfo.GetBranchNo(System.String)
member.summary: Parses an item version number and returns the first branch letter as an integer.

remarks.para: "1a1" returns 1
"1b1" returns 2
"1z1" returns 26
"1aa1" returns 27
"1ba1" returns 53

member.name: M:SystemWeaver.Common.Internal.SWBranchInfo.SplitVersionNumber(System.String,System.String@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Splits the version number into 2 parts. The last version number and the part before.
member.param: Returns everything befor the last version integer

remarks.para: "1a1" returns base="1a", no=1
"2a1b12" returns base="2a1b" no=12

member.name: F:SystemWeaver.Common.SWAttributeDataType.Custom

summary.para: Used to represent a custom attribute.
Custom attributes should be used when you need new attribute-values not covered by the standard built-in editors.
In general zlib compressed UTF-16 xml are used for structured data, but depending on circumstances suitable binary formats may be used.

member.remarks: Custom attributes should be used when you need your own attributes which does not use the built in standard editors. In general zlib zipped xml are preferred for structured data, but binary data storage formats

summary.para: Used to represent a boolean value.
The values are stored as strings, 'True' or 'False'.
Used to represent integer values.
Values are stored in string format as decimal numbers.
Used to represent floating point values.
Values are stored in string format as decimal numbers with decimal point. Example:
Used to represent single line strings. The strings are encoded into bytes by Encoding.Unicode.GetString(AData).
Represents an enumeration.
The values as stored as strings.
The contains an xml which defines the valid enumeration values and associated colors. To get just the enumeration values you can use .
[Mainly for future use] Used when storing xml documents.
There is yet no real support for this attribute datatype.
Values are stored as a zlib compressed UTF-16 string, i.e. through ZCompressBytes(Encoding.Unicode.GetBytes(AString)) where ZCompressBytes is zlib compression.
Used to represent a date and time value.

This attribute is stored as a string of the format: 'YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss' and the application is responsible for converting this to an internal date and time representation and then use the settings from the operation system to display the date in a format acceptable to the user.
Used to represent longer texts.
Values are stored as a zlib compressed UTF-16 string, i.e. through ZCompressBytes(Encoding.Unicode.GetBytes(AString)) where ZCompressBytes is zlib compression.
Used for formatted text.
The values are stored in the same format as the description texts.
Used to have an attribute referencing a SystemWeaver user.
The attribute values are not stored in the value property of IswAttribute, but are managed through the interface .
Used to represent values given by url's.
The value is stored as zlib compressed xml. For datadimension single the format is:
and for datadimension array the format is

member.summary: The item belongs to the trunk. There is only 1 trunk.

member.summary: This item version is an immediate branch of another item.

member.name: F:SystemWeaver.Common.SWAttributeDataDimension.Single
member.summary: Attribute value should be exactly one value of specified data-type.

member.name: F:SystemWeaver.Common.SWAttributeDataDimension.Array
member.summary: Attribute value should consist of an array of values. One value may occur several times.

member.name: F:SystemWeaver.Common.SWAttributeDataDimension.Set
member.summary: Attribute value should consist of set of values. Each value should appear at most once.

member.name: T:SystemWeaver.Common.SWWorkflowStatusType
member.summary: This enumeration specifies the type of a workflow status, open or closed.
member.remarks: The status type affects when issues are shown in different views. Since you generally don't delete issues, the longer a project runs, the more issues you have, and there is a chance that you loose track of what to do since you only see things you have done. By setting an issue to a status with type Closed you indicate that you are done with this issue and don't want to see it any more.

member.name: F:SystemWeaver.Common.SWWorkflowStatusType.Open
member.summary: The issue should be visible.

member.name: F:SystemWeaver.Common.SWWorkflowStatusType.Closed
member.summary: You are finished with this issue and don't want to see it anymore.

member.name: T:SystemWeaver.Common.SWIterationStatus
member.summary: This enumeration specifies the status of an iteration, active or closed.

member.name: F:SystemWeaver.Common.SWIterationStatus.Active
member.summary: The iteration is active.

member.name: F:SystemWeaver.Common.SWIterationStatus.Closed
member.summary: The iteration is closed. Is hidden in views since it is over and done with.

member.summary: This enumeration represents the different item statuses. The Statuses represents the workflow between versions of an item.

member.name: F:SystemWeaver.Common.SWItemStatus.Work
member.summary: Status work, an item can be edited by those with write permissions.

member.name: F:SystemWeaver.Common.SWItemStatus.Frozen
member.summary: Frozen, i.e. ReadOnly. The item can not be edited but the status can still be changed back to Work for editing.

member.name: F:SystemWeaver.Common.SWItemStatus.Released
member.summary: The item can no longer be changed, but other items that this item references may still be changed.

member.name: F:SystemWeaver.Common.SWItemStatus.CSReleased
member.summary: The item can no longer be changed, and all items referenced by this item (and the items referenced by them, and so on) can no longer be changed.

member.name: F:SystemWeaver.Common.SWItemStatus.CheckedOut
member.summary: The item has been checked out by one user and can only be edited by that user.

member.summary: Reads a SystemWeaver system variable as a byte array. If the variable of that name does not exist an empty array is returned.

member.remarks: See for a discussion about SystemWeaver system variables.

member.name: M:SystemWeaver.Common.IswBroker.SetSystemVariableData(System.String,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Reads a SystemWeaver system variable as a byte array. If a variable with that name does not exist an empty string is returned.
member.param: The qualified name of the system variable.
The value as a byte array.

remarks.para: System variables are a way to store key-value pairs, and can be used for a number of purposes.
One common application is to store server/database-specific application configuration data. Another example is that this is how SystemWeaver internally stores password policy settings.
For a simple string value use the Get/SetSystemVariableString methods.
For store structured information, compressed XML is the preferred format, and you use the Get/SetSystemVariableData methods to access the system variable. The max data-length is 131071 bytes.
System variables can also be used to manage unique id counters, see .

There is no name-space concept, so make sure to choose a naming convention for your application that ensures that you do not collide with variable-names used by other applications. Names starting with # are by convention reserved for internal use.

member.name: M:SystemWeaver.Common.IswBroker.IncreaseSystemVariable(System.String)
member.summary: Used to atomically increase an integer-valued system variable by one.
member.param: The qualified name of the system variable.

remarks.para: If the value of the named user-variable is not a valid integer then the counter is reset and 1 is returned.

This method enables the use of system variables to manage unique id counters. The increase of the value is done as an atomic operation, which means that even if 2 users call this method at the same time, the server will execute them serially and the value returned by the call will be different for the two users.
Observe that the counter may be reset by calling , so the server by itself cannot guarantee that the given integer is forever unique.

member.param: A String containing zero or more field codes.

member.name: M:SystemWeaver.Common.IswBroker.GetGlobalIssueRefTypes
member.summary: Returns all global issue ref types.

remarks.para: Issue ref types are defined per project. However, there also exists global issue-ref-types which are automatically available to all issue management project. These global issue-ref-types, cannot be created, but are provided by the platform, the server.
Today there are 2 blobal issue-ref-types defined:

list.item: IR - Item references, the default untyped relationship between issue and items.
DR - Description references, the automatically managed way to, in issues, insert description references to items through the description editor.

member.name: M:SystemWeaver.Common.IswBroker.RemoveItems(SystemWeaver.Common.IswItems,SystemWeaver.Common.IswItems@)
member.summary: Tries to removes several items in one operation.
member.param: List of items to be removed.
Returns items which could not be removed.

remarks.para: This method will try to remove as many of the supplied items as possible.
It was created to take care of the case where you have items referring to each other and you want to remove them without getting: "Cannot remove referenced item".
It can also provide a substantial performance boost if you for some reason want to remove many items in one go.
It can still fail if the items are referenced by other items not included in the list of items to be removed.
If will also fail on those items the current user do not have the permissions to remove .

member.name: P:SystemWeaver.Common.IswBroker.SecurityLevel
member.summary: Gets and sets the security level.

remarks.para: The security level is a number used to determine how permissions on libraries and items are interpreted. The security level is number between 0 and 2.

list.item: 0, 1 - are the same. This is the default security level. Everybody has read access. Everybody has write access unless an item or library has explicit permissions in which case the explicit settings are used.
2 - Everybody still has read access. To get write access you have to explicity set the permission on items or
3 - Read access is not automatically added, but follows the same rules as write access and has to be explicitly set.

remarks.para: Root and owner always have the ability to change permissions. A user with role viewer never has write access.

member.name: P:SystemWeaver.Common.IswLibrary.AccessIsInherited
member.summary: Gets and sets whether access should be inherited.
member.remarks: That access is inherited means that if you change the access for the parent library the access of this library will automatically be changed to reflect the access of the parent library. Thus, if a user or group has access specified in the parent library, that will be the access rights for that user or group in this library, and cannot be changed in this library. But, you can still modify access to users or groups not specified in the parent library.

member.summary: Interface representing a systemweaver item, also called base item, as it is a base class for both library items and config items.

member.summary: When using-item inheritance, checks if this item "is" another item.
member.returns: True if this item "is" specified item.
member.remarks: Item-inheritance is meant to work like object-inheritance with corresponding is-operator. This is not to be confused with the inheritance for item-types.

member.name: M:SystemWeaver.Common.IswItem.NewVersion(System.Boolean,SystemWeaver.Common.IswLibrary)
member.summary: Creates a new version of an item.
member.param: Default true. Set to false if you want to create a branch.

param.name: library
param.para: Default the new version ends up in the same library as this item. Supply this if you want the new version to end up somewhere else.

member.remarks: If there already is a new trunk version of the item, a branch will always be created, ignoring the isBranch property.
member.exception: Will be thrown if the currently logged in user does not have write permissions in the library where the new version is to be created.

member.name: M:SystemWeaver.Common.IswItem.CloseBranch(SystemWeaver.Common.IswItem,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Closes a branch and sets the item it has been merged to.
member.remarks: A branch can only be closed if this item is in a branch. The branch must be open, and cannot have a later main version. The specified item this item is merged into must be part of the same item chain, but must not create a cyclic version graph.
member.param: The item the branch should be merged to.
Indicates whether the contents of the this item should be automatically merged into the mergeTo item.
member.exception: If the requirements in the remarks section are not satisfied.

member.name: M:SystemWeaver.Common.IswItem.Copy
member.summary: [Avoid.] Creates a copy of the item, as in new version but no version relationship is established.
member.remarks: This method is not currently in use in the SystemWeaver explorer based applications.

member.name: M:SystemWeaver.Common.IswItem.FindPartItem(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the item that is pointed to by DefObj in the part of type partTypeSID.

remarks.para: This method is essentially the same as FindPartObj but the result is cast as an IswItem.
This method is primarily intended for use with part-types of multiplicity single. For part-types of multiplicity list, use GetParts instead.

returns.para: The found item. If an item is not found, either because no part(s) exists or if the DefObj is not an item, then the method returns null.
If there are several parts of that part-type on the item, then the DefObj of the first part will be returned.

member.name: M:SystemWeaver.Common.IswItem.StatusEditable
member.summary: Checks if the item is in an editable item-status, i.e. in status Work.
member.returns: True if the item is in an editable item-status.
member.remarks:
Also returns true for the obsolete status CheckedOut.
Observe that you should not use this property if you want to check if the current user can change the item. Just use the property which takes into account the item-status, among other things.

member.name: M:SystemWeaver.Common.IswItem.NameAndVersion
member.summary: Returns the standard representation of name and version.
member.returns: The name and version in one string.
member.remarks: The representation is the name followed by the version in parentheses, i.e. %name%(%version%).

member.name: M:SystemWeaver.Common.IswItem.GetAllReferences(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: [Expensive] Gets all items which, in on step or several, references this item.
member.param: The path is either the empty string or a string of type "sid1;sid2;sid3;...".
Only valid when path is the empty string. Set True if you want to include later versions of this item and referencing items.
member.returns: For empty string, returns all items which in some way, not neccesary directly, references this item. If a path is given, only those items which references this item through the given exact path are returned.
member.remarks: I.e. for empty string, returns all items that, which if you where to open the complete status view, this item would be somewhere among the recursively referenced items. I you give a path you can use * to denote that the given sid are allowed zero or more times, similarly to the * in regular expressions.

member.name: T:SystemWeaver.Common.SWObjectRefTable
member.summary: This is the class responsible for wrapping the rvf in the descriptions. It adds a translation table at the beginning used to map internal sequence numbers (internal to the data wrapped) to handles. These handles are then automatically updated by the server when a new version is created. References to parts in the old item are replaced by references to parts in the new item.

member.summary: Default constructor

member.summary: Clears the table.

member.summary: Gets the byte array consisting of the managed translation table together with the data it is suppposed to wrap.
member.returns: The byte array and the data in on byte array.

member.summary: Loads a saved transalation table, and returns the wrapped data.

member.summary: Adds a handle to the translation table returns a new id used to retrieve the handle.

member.summary: Returns if a given handle exists in the table.
member.returns: True if the handle exists in the table

member.summary: Gets the number of handles in the translation table.

member.summary: Utility class containing functions for working with the attribute-type range property.

remarks.para: A SystemWeaver range is currently represented as a zlib compressed xml.
This representation may be changed in the future to allow for extended functionality, so please use these help-functions instead of parsing the xml on your own.
For attributes of type enumeration the internal representation is:
For attributes of type string you can put a regular expression constraint represented by the xml:
